article.title: Colour gradients in cluster ellipticals at z 1.4: the hidden content of the galaxy central regions

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the left panel of Figure 1 show?
choices: The distribution of i775 - z850 colour for all galaxies in the cluster.
The relation between i775 - z850 colour and z850 magnitude for elliptical galaxies in the cluster.
The relation between i775 - z850 colour and z850 magnitude for all galaxies in the cluster.
The redshift distribution of elliptical galaxies in the cluster.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information does the right panel of Figure 1 provide?
choices: The distribution of z850 magnitudes for all galaxies within 1 Mpc from the cluster centre.
The distribution of i775 - z850 colour for all galaxies within 1 Mpc from the cluster centre.
The distribution of redshifts for all galaxies within 1 Mpc from the cluster centre.
The distribution of stellar masses for all galaxies within 1 Mpc from the cluster centre.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the solid red line in the right panel of Figure 1 represent?
choices: The mean i775 - z850 colour of the 5 spectroscopically confirmed cluster members.
The median i775 - z850 colour of the 5 spectroscopically confirmed cluster members.
The mean i775 - z850 colour of all galaxies within 1 Mpc from the cluster centre.
The median i775 - z850 colour of all galaxies within 1 Mpc from the cluster centre.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the second peak in the i775 - z850 colour distribution (right panel)?
choices: It indicates the presence of a population of galaxies with lower redshifts within the cluster.
It indicates the presence of a population of galaxies with higher redshifts within the cluster.
It indicates the presence of a population of galaxies with younger stellar populations within the cluster.
It indicates the presence of a population of galaxies with older stellar populations within the cluster.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main purpose of showing galaxy 2809 in Figure 2?
choices: To demonstrate the morphological differences between elliptical and spiral galaxies at z=1.39.
To illustrate the effect of blending on photometric measurements at different resolutions.
To show the difference in the stellar population properties of galaxies at different wavelengths.
To highlight the importance of using multiple telescopes for studying galaxies at high redshift.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which image has the lowest resolution and therefore shows the two galaxies as fully blended?
choices: ACS-F850LP (left panel).
HAWKI J (central panel).
Spitzer-IRAC 3.6 µm (right panel).
All three images have the same resolution.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the implication of blending on the photometry of galaxy 2809 in the Spitzer-IRAC 3.6 µm band?
choices: The measured flux will be an underestimate of the true flux of galaxy 2809.
The measured flux will be an overestimate of the true flux of galaxy 2809.
The measured flux will not be affected by blending.
Blending has no effect on the photometry of galaxies.

multiple_choice_question.text: How do the authors address the issue of blending in the Spitzer-IRAC photometry of blended galaxies?
choices: They exclude blended galaxies from their analysis.
They use higher resolution images from other telescopes to deblend the galaxies.
They redistribute the total IRAC flux of the blended sources based on fluxes measured in other bands.
They do not address the issue of blending.
The observed colour profiles of two galaxies as a function of radius.
The intrinsic colour profiles of two galaxies as a function of radius.
The evolution of colour gradients with redshift.
The relation between colour gradients and galaxy morphology.

multiple_choice_question.text: What are the red lines in Figure 3?
choices: The best-fitted logarithmic slopes of the colour profiles.
The predicted colour gradients from stellar population synthesis models.
The colour gradients measured from the observed colour profiles.
The metallicity gradients derived from the colour gradients.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the opposite slopes of the F775W-F850LP and F850LP-F160W colour gradients?
choices: It suggests a radial variation of both age and metallicity in the galaxies.
It suggests a radial variation of dust extinction in the galaxies.
It implies a UV excess towards the galaxy central regions.
It indicates the presence of recent star formation in the outskirts of the galaxies.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is the width of the colour interval the same (∆colour=1 mag) for both F775W-F850LP and F850LP-F160W colours?
choices: To ensure that the colour gradients are measured over the same physical scales.
To facilitate the comparison of the slopes of the two colour gradients.
To account for the different resolutions of the ACS and WFC3 images.
To avoid introducing spurious gradients due to the PSF.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the relationship between colour gradients and effective radius (Re) shown in Figure 4?
choices: Galaxies with larger Re tend to have steeper colour gradients.
Galaxies with larger Re tend to have flatter colour gradients.
There is no clear correlation between colour gradients and Re.
The relationship between colour gradients and Re is complex and depends on other factors.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the negative values of log(Re(775)/Re(850)) imply?
choices: The effective radius is smaller in the bluer F775W band compared to the redder F850LP band.
The effective radius is larger in the bluer F775W band compared to the redder F850LP band.
The effective radii in the two bands are the same.
The effective radius is not a reliable indicator of colour gradients.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the grey crosses in Figure 4?
choices: They represent elliptical galaxies at z~1.25 from a previous study.
They represent field galaxies at z~1.25 from a previous study.
They represent cluster galaxies at z~1.25 from a previous study.
They represent simulated galaxies used to test the analysis method.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion that can be drawn from Figure 4?
choices: Cluster galaxies at z~1.4 show a wider range of colour gradients than those at lower redshifts.
Cluster galaxies at z~1.4 show similar colour gradients to those at lower redshifts.
The relationship between colour gradients and effective radius changes with redshift.
Colour gradients are not a reliable indicator of the evolution of elliptical galaxies.
